commit_message:
Move the frequently injection task to the base folder.

Key/value injection is a typical way to bootstrap a
dependency based system (as there needs to be an
initial set of values to depend on). Since this inject
task is frequently used to accomplish this we should
just move it to the base file.

Change-Id: Ib49e949f319bc18744fc95f8a02fab1eade0fb6a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/26/43026/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: api_flow.add(base.InjectTask(create_what, addons=[ACTION])) scheduler_flow.add(base.InjectTask({ }, addons=[ACTION])) volume_flow.add(base.InjectTask({ }, addons=[ACTION]))
deleted_lines: class ValuesInjectTask(base.CinderTask): """This injects a dict into the flow. This injection is done so that the keys (and values) provided can be dependended on by tasks further down the line. Since taskflow is dependency based this can be considered the bootstrapping task that provides an initial set of values for other tasks to get started with. If this did not exist then tasks would fail locating there dependent tasks and the values said dependent tasks produce. Reversion strategy: N/A """ def __init__(self, inject_what): super(ValuesInjectTask, self).__init__(addons=[ACTION]) self.provides.update(inject_what.keys()) self._inject = inject_what def __call__(self, context): return dict(self._inject) api_flow.add(ValuesInjectTask(create_what)) scheduler_flow.add(ValuesInjectTask({ })) volume_flow.add(ValuesInjectTask({ }))

 (/opt/stack/new/oslo.config),

Change-Id: I9090b8401a43befd73a82f9bb78e0b6165619c7c

commit_message:
Remove explicit version from setup.cfg

With the explicit "pre version" in setup.cfg, PBR generates our
version as 1.2.0.a1.g2748574 and, without it, it generates
1.2.0a4.1.g2748574.

which in turn causes nova to complain about:

 VersionConflict: (oslo.config 1.2.0.a1.g2748574
 (/opt/stack/new/oslo.config),
 Requirement.parse('oslo.config>=1.2.0a3'))

when trying to load extensions with stevedore.

I'm not sure why this is suddenly an issue after 1.2.0a4 has been
tagged, but removing this version is the right thing to do anyway
since we want to rely on tags for all versioning info.

Change-Id: I9090b8401a43befd73a82f9bb78e0b6165619c7c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo.config refs/changes/19/43619/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
VMware: fix rescue/unrescue instance

Fixes bug 1199955

The problem is due to the way in which the VM's are named on vCenter.
That is, in Nova a VM has a name and a UUID. In vCenter the VM only
has a name. The VM name on vCenter is Nova's instance UUID. When the
rescue/unrescue operation takes place a new VM is spawned/destroyed.
The Nova VM has the name '<name>-rescue'. The problem is that the
new rescue name was not passed correctly to the vCenter, that is,
it should have been '<uuid>-rescue' but it was just '<uuid>'. This
caused the opertaion to fail as there is already a VM with that name
on vCenter. A new name should have been passed which is '<uuid>-rescue'.

Change-Id: Icfe6e5021b29026788bec8f3526f94a8ec0a65e2

commit_message:
User quota update should not exceed project quota

When user quota is not set, the default quota set in
config file will be used as the default user quota,
this will break the logic of user quota (the default
user quota should be restricted by the project quota)

Fixes bug 1208400
Fixes bug 1205582

Change-Id: Id98d504d8f5e0dda642fa5e7c550acea79520c3d

commit_message:
Only create user_creds row on initial stack store

We should only store the credentials on inital stack store,
otherwise we end up creating orphan user_creds rows every
time the stack status is updated.

Fixes bug #1197074

commit_message:
remove unused config options

There are several historical cut/paste unused options, which have
also now found there way into heat.conf.sample, which will confuse
users, so best to remove them.

Fixes bug #1215834

Change-Id: I0fe4717327fc67fe109bef4ba1758d2f18e84520

commit_message:
python3: Fix UserString import

In python3 UserString got moved to collections. This results in the
following traceback while running with python3:

ImportError: No module named 'UserString'

Change-Id: Ica44cd027e012e13828c0a84b3b36607cc92fe69
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-incubator refs/changes/26/42326/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: try: from UserString import UserString except ImportError: from collections import UserStringclass Message(UserString, object): return UserString.__getattribute__(self, name)
deleted_lines: import UserStringclass Message(UserString.UserString, object): return UserString.UserString.__getattribute__(self, name)

commit_message:
Skip devstack/exercises by default

In order to avoid maintaining test cases in two location,
the devstack/exercises should be disabled when tempest is enabled.

The exercises is preserved for grande and stable branch jobs.

A smaller/faster 'smoke' test case set can be selected from the tempest
test cases if it is needed.

Fixing bug #1023131

Change-Id: Icac3998fb2c18274d909afcff8708af149d68197

commit_message:
Process request exceptions while fetching template

requests raises subclass of requests.exception.RequestException, not
IOError. And the code explicitly calls raise_for_status to avoid HTTP
errors being silently ignored.

Fixes bug #1214429

Change-Id: Ib3ea7e4fea459a231f0bb7f113e3d66983b006c2
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/49/43149/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from requests import exceptions try: resp = requests.get(url) resp.raise_for_status() return resp.text except exceptions.RequestException as ex: raise IOError('Failed to retrieve template: %s' % str(ex))

commit_message:
Use system locale when Accept-Language header is not provided

Remove en_US as the default language when no header is provided, and use
None instead. Upon translation None will be defaulted to system as it
was before the translation changes.

Fixes bug: #1214476

Change-Id: I0fe22c526710e69ae0731e7d0b42170e6f3a8523

commit_message:
Fix incorrect use of ServerError

ServerError is being incorrectly used to report an internal error
leading to an error formatting the response, as there's no body
specified to the format string.  Use exception.Error instead and
adjust the message to make the user-visible response clearer.

Fixes bug #1214457

Change-Id: I83435686170c4f40658968a35f1faa303f50f4a4

commit_message:
Move sections of nova.conf into partials

Moved larger sections of nova.conf into partials.  Also, attempted
to categorize flags that were in the wrong place.  I would concider
this a stepping stone to oslo.

Change-Id: I199a03d5d8cae4b20efcbad6ded9cfa8fb61aa67

commit_message:
Use elevated context as intended

Rectoring introduced in Id8f81419fbbc3616e216e4da0c16898757905933
was not quite complete, and it missed to change the context needed
to create and destroy the metadata network.

Fix bug #1216110

Change-Id: I2161b07f5cd09654f714e237cb4277e8bc60fff1

commit_message:
Add a method of creating a backup stack in the DB

This is a temporary storage place for resources that are going to be
deleted once their replacements are created. They must be moved out of
the stack in order to avoid conflicting with the replacement resource.

Change-Id: I081498f4c8732f893dc0d0677cf2b3f40f56d808
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/51/43551/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if owner_id is None: if re.match("[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9_.-]*$", stack_name) is None: raise ValueError(_('Invalid stack name %s' ' must contain only alphanumeric or ' '\"_-.\" characters, must start with alpha' ) % stack_name) def store(self, backup=False): 'name': self._backup_name() if backup else self.name, def _backup_name(self): return '%s*' % self.name def _backup_stack(self): ''' Get a Stack containing any in-progress resources from the previous stack state prior to an update. ''' s = db_api.stack_get_by_name(self.context, self._backup_name(), owner_id=self.id) if s is not None: logger.debug('Loaded existing backup stack') return self.load(self.context, stack=s) else: prev = type(self)(self.context, self.name, self.t, self.env, owner_id=self.id) prev.store(backup=True) logger.debug('Created new backup stack') return prev
deleted_lines: if re.match("[a-zA-Z][a-zA-Z0-9_.-]*$", stack_name) is None: raise ValueError(_('Invalid stack name %s' ' must contain only alphanumeric or ' '\"_-.\" characters, must start with alpha' ) % stack_name) def store(self): 'name': self.name,

subject: Allow a Provider with a known facade its own schema
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-19 18:53:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/heat/commit/e45bb9aece87e618c834b1107e1f6b522f66a8c0', 'message': 'Allow a Provider with a known facade its own schema

Allow a TemplateResource behind the facade of a known plugin to supply a
different schema to the facade resource. However, check during validation
that the two are basically compatible. The provider template must:

- Define parameters for all *required* properties of the facade.

commit_message:
Allow a Provider with a known facade its own schema

Allow a TemplateResource behind the facade of a known plugin to supply a
different schema to the facade resource. However, check during validation
that the two are basically compatible. The provider template must:

- Define parameters for all *required* properties of the facade.
- Define parameters that map to the same types as the facade properties.
- Not have *required* parameters that do not exist in the facade.
- Define outputs for all attributes of the facade.

Change-Id: Ie40ecbb43d3d6749266f2cb6d723c8537fcc23dd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/05/42705/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from heat.common import exception tmpl = template.Template(self.parsed_nested) self.properties_schema = (properties.Properties .schema_from_params(tmpl.param_schemata())) self.attributes_schema = (attributes.Attributes .schema_from_outputs(tmpl[template.OUTPUTS])) def validate(self): # Look for an existing type used as a facade for this template cls_facade = resource.get_class(self.type()) if not isinstance(self, cls_facade): # Check for compatibility with the facade facade_schemata = properties.schemata(cls_facade.properties_schema) for n, fs in facade_schemata.items(): if fs.required and n not in self.properties_schema: msg = ("Required property %s for facade %s " "missing in provider") % (n, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) ps = self.properties_schema.get(n) if (n in self.properties_schema and (fs.type != ps.type)): # Type mismatch msg = ("Property %s type mismatch between facade %s (%s) " "and provider (%s)") % (n, self.type(), fs.type, ps.type) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) for n, ps in self.properties_schema.items(): if ps.required and n not in facade_schemata: # Required property for template not present in facade msg = ("Provider requires property %s " "unknown in facade %s") % (n, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) for attr in cls_facade.attributes_schema: if attr not in self.attributes_schema: msg = ("Attribute %s for facade %s " "missing in provider") % (attr, self.type()) raise exception.StackValidationFailed(message=msg) return super(TemplateResource, self).validate()
deleted_lines: # on purpose don't pass in the environment so we get # the official/facade class in case we need to copy it's schema. cls_facade = resource.get_class(json_snippet['Type']) # if we're not overriding via the environment, mirror the template as # a new resource if cls_facade == self.__class__: tmpl = template.Template(self.parsed_nested) self.properties_schema = (properties.Properties .schema_from_params(tmpl.param_schemata())) self.attributes_schema = (attributes.Attributes .schema_from_outputs(tmpl[template.OUTPUTS])) # otherwise we are overriding a resource type via the environment # and should mimic that type else: self.properties_schema = cls_facade.properties_schema self.attributes_schema = cls_facade.attributes_schema

commit_message:
Evaluate lazy translation in exception __str__

The OpenStackException.__str__ method returns
self._error_string which is actually a gettextutil.Message
object not a str.

str(o) will check the return type of o.__str__() and raise
TypeError if __str__ returns non-string object.

The fix will not go into oslo as OpenStackException is
about to be deprecated. And this patch is also the first
step to remove all the references to oslo exception.py.

Fixes bug #1208454

Change-Id: Ib6abe3517bcb1b34fc6a71e5c46ee3774e067f9a

commit_message:
Do not obscure Unauthorized error messages

All Unauthorized exceptions are currently trapped and
the following message is printed:
    Invalid OpenStack Identity credentials.

This is unhelpful now that heat-api is providing structured
errors with (sometimes) helpful context for authorization failures.

This change removes this error trapping and prints the intended
error message.

Change-Id: Ibd943deb1f365e5f212225be1e675beb14accf97

commit_message:
Fixed a network setup issue for F19

IP address is passed as a kernel boot param when booting undercloud
machine. For Fedora 19, this IP is not set, instead IP is fetched
from DHCP.

The problem is caused by a bug in dracut-network version 029, which
causes that dracut network setup script is not executed properly. This
patch applies a fix for the bug when building undercloud image.

Fixes: bug #1213833
Change-Id: Ie94a86ed716044343791628973143c1a7d0778dc

commit_message:
Handling re-delete in rackspace db resource

Current implementation of db resource throws exception if the
resource was already deleted(All the other resources are not
throwing). This fix is to make db resource behavior similar to
other resources.

Fixes Bug #1197077

Change-Id: I4537180115400e6f6183e72a74bdd3ada220a3fa

commit_message:
Replace httplib with requests for ec2tokens auth

This vastly simplifies the implementation and test mocking.

ec2token middleware is the last piece of code in the heat
repository to be making direct httplib calls.

Change-Id: I3807b27a7699ff19eb46e2721aaa5afd9d6c8ff9
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/heat refs/changes/04/43204/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import requests response = requests.post(keystone_ec2_uri, data=creds_json, headers=headers) result = response.json()
deleted_lines: import urlparse import httplib # Disable 'has no x member' pylint error # for httplib and urlparse # pylint: disable-msg=E1101 o = urlparse.urlparse(keystone_ec2_uri) if o.scheme == 'http': conn = httplib.HTTPConnection(o.netloc) else: conn = httplib.HTTPSConnection(o.netloc) conn.request('POST', o.path, body=creds_json, headers=headers) response = conn.getresponse().read() conn.close() # NOTE(vish): We could save a call to keystone by # having keystone return token, tenant, # user, and roles from this call. result = json.loads(response)

commit_message:
Support array values in command

Description of command in CFN User Guide:

Either an array or a string specifying the command to run. If you use
an array, you do not need to escape space characters or enclose
command parameters in quotes.

So we escape double quote first, and enclose each array value in
double quote.

Fixes bug #1211605

Change-Id: I28ecdb0d4b8a12690dddeac4e2398264c6d6f212

commit_message:
remove flake8 option from run_tests.sh

flake8 will read the section [flake8] of tox.ini to guide the
behavior. In run_tests.sh, the function run_flake8() does not
need the falke8 option any more.

Fixes Bug #1214159
Change-Id: I1bbba279a339e35c776a6969598b398f57fd7646

commit_message:
Add v1 API x-image-meta- header whitelist

Add a whitelist of allowed 'x-image-meta-xxx' style
headers. Attempts to supply other, unexpected headers
will return 400.

This prevents cases such as 'x-image-meta-locations'
being processed, which were not being handled correctly.

Addresses bug 1205018.

Change-Id: I771bb6ae2a4f9cbd7726f952c7a71da99162b490
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/34/38834/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Whitelist of v1 API headers of form x-image-meta-xxx IMAGE_META_HEADERS = ['x-image-meta-location', 'x-image-meta-size', 'x-image-meta-is_public', 'x-image-meta-disk_format', 'x-image-meta-container_format', 'x-image-meta-name', 'x-image-meta-status', 'x-image-meta-copy_from', 'x-image-meta-uri', 'x-image-meta-checksum', 'x-image-meta-created_at', 'x-image-meta-updated_at', 'x-image-meta-deleted-at', 'x-image-meta-min_ram', 'x-image-meta-min_disk', 'x-image-meta-owner', 'x-image-meta-store', 'x-image-meta-id', 'x-image-meta-protected'] if 'x-image-meta-' + field_name not in IMAGE_META_HEADERS: msg = _(("Bad header: %s") % key) raise exc.HTTPBadRequest(msg, content_type="text/plain")

commit_message:
Add an admin API endpoint

Add an admin API endpoint to Nova.  This is intended to be an endpoint
only exposed internally to the deployment.  It will be used for
integration with other services, such as Cinder or Neutron.

By default, the admin API listens on port 35359.  When adding
information to the Keystone service catalog, this new port should be
used for the adminURL.

As of this commit, the API exposed by this endpoint is identical to that
of the regular API.  However, hooks are provided for adding admin API
endpoint specific API extensions.  This will be utilized in future
commits.

Implements blueprint admin-api

DocImpact

Change-Id: Ib9c22cd970d598b34618d9c91c779477aa1d4004

'compute.contrib.select_admin_extensions'),def standard_admin_extensions(ext_mgr): standard_extensions(ext_mgr) admin_path = [os.path.join(__path__[0], '..', 'contrib_admin')] extensions.load_standard_extensions(ext_mgr, LOG, admin_path, __package__) def select_admin_extensions(ext_mgr): extensions.load_standard_extensions(ext_mgr, LOG, __path__, __package__, CONF.osapi_compute_admin_ext_list)

commit_message:
Add i18n support for RPC timeout message

The change 284b13adfb88018d58e0c7c4bfe840d1db1e8f6b did not
add this support.

Change-Id: Ic467c2eb0d999a3e4529b0a24f8682775fde5d4a

commit_message:
remove flake8 option in run_tests.sh

flake8 read [flake8] section of tox.ini as options.

function run_flake8 in run_tests.sh should be kept simple,
and tox.ini controls the behavior of flake8.

Fixes Bug #1212988

Change-Id: I35d434ccea1ca2f3ff93657e4ca6dde93bbbf29e

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-16 05:52:14.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/tests/fake_driver.py', 'bin/cinder-manage', 'cinder/tests/api/v1/test_volumes.py', 'bin/cinder-rootwrap', 'cinder/wsgi.py', 'cinder/tests/api/v1/test_snapshots.py', 'bin/cinder-volume-usage-audit', 'cinder/tests/api/contrib/test_types_extra_specs.py', 'cinder/tests/api/v2/test_volumes.py', 'cinder/tests/image/test_glance.py', 'cinder/tests/api/v2/test_snapshots.py', 'cinder/tests/test_test.py', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/7ba73b5fe328274dbd36b453f367dff50b62f824', 'message': 'flake8 check: H233 the print operator

As the H233 checking is added into Python package "hacking",
the print operator problem is exposed.

H233:
Check that all occurrences look like print functions, not
print operator.

As of Python 3.x, the print operator has been removed.

Okay: print(msg)
Okay: print (msg)
H233: print msg

'}]
commit_message:
flake8 check: H233 the print operator

As the H233 checking is added into Python package "hacking",
the print operator problem is exposed.

H233:
Check that all occurrences look like print functions, not
print operator.

As of Python 3.x, the print operator has been removed.

Okay: print(msg)
Okay: print (msg)
H233: print msg
H233: print >>sys.stderr, "hello"
H233: print msg,

Fix the print operator and the consequent falke8 issues, and
enable H233 in tox.ini.

Fixes Bug #1211130

Change-Id: I52554692717b22fc0bfea56e62e9f87756cc5b16

commit_message:
Storwize/SVC: allow setting of I/O group

Allow setting the I/O group via config option or volume type. Also
updated comments and checks regarding iSCSI multipath, which is in Nova
and is not controlled by the driver.

Fixes: bug 1215363

Change-Id: Ia67fcb9991e21990cc81830145b8fd934a23488e

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-21 11:13:29.000000000', 'files': ['run_tests.sh'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/8619b974d17a186dc1013bfdc9d95f6a2e823335', 'message': 'emit warning while running flake8 without virtual env

run_tests.sh -N -p
it will call the flake8 installed on your host to detect PEP8, and
the flake8 plugin "OpenStack hacking" may not installed on your
host, so this command may not detect the OpenStack Style Commandment
supplied by hacking(e.g H202).

run_tests.sh -p
it will call the flake8 from virtual env, flake8 plugin "OpenStack
hacking" installed in virtual env will be triggered.

virtual env to run flake8 too.

When "-N" is enabled, emit warning to remind user.

Bug #1208584

Change-Id: Ie08e5fa2b44088dad135e11583c046650d65df1e
'}]
commit_message:
emit warning while running flake8 without virtual env

run_tests.sh -N -p
it will call the flake8 installed on your host to detect PEP8, and
the flake8 plugin "OpenStack hacking" may not installed on your
host, so this command may not detect the OpenStack Style Commandment
supplied by hacking(e.g H202).

run_tests.sh -p
it will call the flake8 from virtual env, flake8 plugin "OpenStack
hacking" installed in virtual env will be triggered.

The result from "run_tests.sh -p" should be trusted, and jenkins uses
virtual env to run flake8 too.

When "-N" is enabled, emit warning to remind user.

Bug #1208584

Change-Id: Ie08e5fa2b44088dad135e11583c046650d65df1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/98/43098/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if [ $never_venv -eq 1 ]; then echo "**WARNING**:" echo "Running flake8 without virtual env may miss OpenStack HACKING detection" fi

commit_message:
Fix volume_glance_metadata deletion

If volume_glance_metadata does not exist for a certain volume,
it returns an exception and does not delete volume from db.
Avoid deleting it if it does not exist.

Bug: 1209367
Change-Id: Ia607ec5ecfc115c1a593f14236ee93158938a8da

commit_message:
Use a new rest client for every Coraid ESM command

It's workaround for the session corruption bug
in the ESM Appliance.

fix bug #1214433

Change-Id: Ie844f3c95675c4d734390c23ed2d421c159ce8a7

commit_message:
Remove print statement in db api test

Remove the encryption related print statements in
test_dp_api, this should bring us up to speed
now for updated requirements and take care of the
py3.3 incompat print issues.

Change-Id: If7475cc43d3c0b443908f846d76071913536fdf4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/89/43589/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: print "values[%s] = %s" % (i, values[i]) print "encryption = %s" % encryption.__dict__ print "encryption = %s" % encryption.__dict__ print "encryption_get = %s" % encryption_get.__dict__

subject: Implement QoS support for volumes
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-05-20 05:45:49.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/ef83896b01287dc9cb34bf8aeaeeddde6b649ecb', 'message': "Add rate limit columns to volume_types table

This is part of the effort to implement client-side volume rate limiting
feature. The idea of client-side volume rate limiting is quite simple: Cinder
stores rate-limiting parameters in for each volume, and then when Nova asks
for connection infomration of volume, Cinder sends back rate limiting
parameters so that Nova can apply to its side via virtualization layer. Take
KVM hypervisor (or libvirt virt layer) for example: with libvirt later than
0.9.8, it's able to put following rate limit controls of a block device for
VM:

  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
    appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
    read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of rate limit
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design in this patch is to bond rate limiting with volume
types. So Cinder admin can create various volume types with different rate
limit controls, and volumes of same volume type have same rate limit
parameters.

To store rate limit parameters with volume types also have two different
options: 1) extend volume type table itself and add new columns for rate limit;
2) use volume_type_extra_spec to store rate limit parameters. While the latter
design seems to have lowest impact of Cinder code, it does bring in new
challenges: Cinder volume manager needs an fixed way (i.e. doesn't reply on how
admin create a volume type) to retrieve rate limiting parameters for volumes,
but extra specs are dynamic by nature (all defined by admin). Therefore, this
patch takes first approach to store rate limiting paramenters, that's adding
new columns to volume_types table. It's generic description of how client (and
/or back-end) should limit throughput/IOPS of volumes, and by default, all rate
limiting parameters are set to zero, which means there's no rate limit of
existing volumes.

This patch changes the internal API interface for creating volume types, so no
impact of compatibility at all. The rest part of the changes needed in Cinder
are:
 * enable volume manager/driver to read and send rate limit parameters to Nova
 in initliaize_connection() call;
 * allow type_manage API extension to process rate limit parameters;
 * enable cinder client to process rate limit parameters when creating new
 volume types.

DocImpact

partically implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

"}, {'number': 7, 'created': '2013-06-05 20:32:59.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/95943cd1908379a65975c34e97df5b3247942454', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
While QoS can mean a lot things, here in this implementation it mainly refers
to throttling/rate-limiting and performance assurance. The goal is 1) to add an
interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to express QoS requirements for
volumes; 2) to define common performance characteristics for volume; 3) to
change scheduler so that it can filter out unqualified back-ends.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

Changes:
  - Add a quality_of_services table to accommadate QoS requirements for volume
  types. Follow eight fields are used to describe performance characteristics:
    * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
      appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
    * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
    * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

    * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
      read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
    * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
    * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

    Two additional keys:
    * 'qos_type' key is to describe the levels of QoS: rate-limit, best effort
      perf assurance and perf guarantee.
    * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
      policy to be enforced.
  - Add 'volume_type_qos' API extension to allow mofication of type QoS.
  - Add 'supported_QoS_types' to host capabilities, lvm/solidfire driver
  changes are made as an example.
  - Add 'qos_specs' to filter properties for a volume create request.
  - Add QoSFilter for filter scheduler.

TODO:
  Add unittests.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2
"}, {'number': 8, 'created': '2013-06-05 20:38:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/5e780094dfe6c752511d4d3eaa3c41b0a0e73ec2', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
While QoS can mean a lot things, here in this implementation it mainly refers
to throttling/rate-limiting and performance assurance. The goal is 1) to add an
interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to express QoS requirements for
volumes; 2) to define common performance characteristics for volume; 3) to
change scheduler so that it can filter out unqualified back-ends.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

Changes:
  - Add a quality_of_services table to accommadate QoS requirements for volume
  types. Follow eight fields are used to describe performance characteristics:
    * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
      appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
    * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
    * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

    * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
      read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
    * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
    * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

    Two additional keys:
    * 'qos_type' key is to describe the levels of QoS: rate-limit, best effort
      perf assurance and perf guarantee.
    * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
      policy to be enforced.
  - Add 'volume_type_qos' API extension to allow mofication of type QoS.
  - Add 'supported_QoS_types' to host capabilities, lvm/solidfire driver
  changes are made as an example.
  - Add 'qos_specs' to filter properties for a volume create request.
  - Add QoSFilter for filter scheduler.

TODO:
  Add unittests.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2
"}, {'number': 9, 'created': '2013-07-18 17:48:22.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/1f64306a770ccf105c2150b89a5784aee2acca04', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is 1) to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume rate-limit, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder
back-end or both; 2) to add an interface so that admins can use to express
QoS requirements for volumes (of specific back-ends), which will be consumed
by back-end drivers.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
intepreation that all vendors can agree on.  On the other hand, the
throttling/rate-limiting is a notion that has clear defintion that everyone
agrees on. So the approach this implementation takes is to break Quality-of-
Service into two parts: throttling/rate-limiting and the rest (free-form,
vender specific defintion).  The free-form part is stored as key/value pairs
as special (under the scope 'QoS_specs:') extra_specs of a volume type, and
the rate-limit control info is stored as part of specification for types (as
new columns for volume_types table).

Changes:
 - Add following 7 columns to volume_types table for rate-limit requirements
 for volume types.
  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
 appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
 read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

  * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
 policy to be enforced, currently these three values are considered valid:
 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end), 'both'.

 - Add a new resource extension to 'types_extra_specs' API extension to allow
 list/create/update/delete of type QoS specs.
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for a volume
 create request.
 - Add rate-limit info to data structure when initialize_connection()

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2
"}, {'number': 10, 'created': '2013-07-18 17:50:42.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/d44b10de3f3793c64c6247a8a8fb384b7650eca1', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

throttling/rate-limiting is a notion that has clear defintion that everyone
agrees on. So the approach this implementation takes is to break Quality-of-
Service into two parts: throttling/rate-limiting and the rest (free-form,
vender specific defintion).  The free-form part is stored as key/value pairs
as special (under the scope 'QoS_specs:') extra_specs of a volume type, and
the rate-limit control info is stored as part of specification for types (as
new columns for volume_types table).

Changes:
 - Add following 7 columns to volume_types table for rate-limit requirements
 for volume types.
  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second. This cannot
 appear with read_bytes_sec or write_bytes_sec.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second. This cannot appear with
 read_iops_sec or write_iops_sec.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

  * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
 policy to be enforced, currently these three values are considered valid:
 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end), 'both'.

 - Add a new resource extension to 'types_extra_specs' API extension to allow
 list/create/update/delete of type QoS specs.
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for a volume
 create request.
 - Add rate-limit info to data structure when initialize_connection()

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is 1) to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume rate-limit, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder
back-end or both; 2) to add an interface so that admins can use to express
QoS requirements for volumes (of specific back-ends), which will be consumed
by back-end drivers.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
intepreation that all vendors can agree on.  On the other hand, the
throttling/rate-limiting is a notion that has clear defintion that everyone
agrees on. So the approach this implementation takes is to break Quality-of-
Service into two parts: throttling/rate-limiting and the rest (free-form,
vender specific defintion).  The free-form part is stored as key/value pairs
as special (under the scope 'QoS_specs:') extra_specs of a volume type, and
the rate-limit control info is stored as part of specification for types (as
new columns for volume_types table).

Changes:
 - Add following 7 columns to volume_types table for rate-limit requirements
 for volume types.
  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

  * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
 policy to be enforced, currently these three values are considered valid:
 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end), 'both'.

 - Add a new resource extension to 'types_extra_specs' API extension to allow
 list/create/update/delete of type QoS specs.
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for a volume
 create request.
 - Add rate-limit info to data structure when initialize_connection()

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

"}, {'number': 13, 'created': '2013-07-24 10:10:56.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/c36f8ed26509b5f45302795798737a144c56c279', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is 1) to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume rate-limit, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder
back-end or both; 2) to add an interface so that admins can use to express
QoS requirements for volumes (of specific back-ends), which will be consumed
by back-end drivers.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can create various volume types with different QoS requirements, and volumes
of same volume type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
intepreation that all vendors can agree on.  On the other hand, the
throttling/rate-limiting is a notion that has clear defintion that everyone
agrees on. So the approach this implementation takes is to break Quality-of-
Service into two parts: throttling/rate-limiting and the rest (free-form,
vender specific defintion).  The free-form part is stored as key/value pairs
as special (under the scope 'QoS_specs:') extra_specs of a volume type, and
the rate-limit control info is stored in a new table called
volume_type_rate_limit.

Changes:
 - Add a volume_type_rate_limit table with following 7 columns to store
 rate-limit requirements for volume types.  Note that unlike extra_specs,
 there's only one rate limit entry per volume type if any, since the rate_limit
 control information has fixed keys.

  * total_bytes_sec: total throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * read_bytes_sec: read throughput limit in bytes per second.
  * write_bytes_sec: write throughput limit in bytes per second.

  * total_iops_sec: total I/O operations per second.
  * read_iops_sec: read I/O operations per second.
  * write_iops_sec: write I/O operations per second.

  * 'control_location' is to store the value where admin would like the QoS
 policy to be enforced, currently these three values are considered valid:
 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end), 'both'.

 - Add a new resource extension to 'types_extra_specs' API extension to allow
 list/create/update/delete of type QoS specs.
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' and 'rate_limit' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.
 - Add 'rate_limit', 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

"}, {'number': 16, 'created': '2013-08-07 18:04:15.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/ff24c0f7d3f63b145e34710b662b8444dca1b39c', 'message': "Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume QoS, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder back-end
or both. QoS specifications are added as a standalone (only visible to admin)
entity.  So admin can create/update/delete and associate/disassociate QoS
specifications to other entities, in this case volume types.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can associate volume types with QoS specifications, and volumes of same volume
type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
interpretation that all vendors can agree on.  So the approach this
implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.
expressed as key/value pairs.

Changes:
 - Add a quality_of_service_specs table, using adjacency list relation to store
 a specs entry and its detailed specs in key/values. Note that to be able to
 distinguish where should the QoS specs be consumed, each QoS specs entity
 will have a 'consumer' (i.e. fixed key) with the value of where admin would
 like the QoS policy to be enforced/consumed, currently these three values are
 considered valid: 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end),
 'both'. The default value for 'consumer' is 'back-end'.

 - Add a new API extension 'qos_specs_manage' to allow list/create/update/
 delete/associate/disassociate of QoS specs.

 TODO
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept rate_limit info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept rate-limit info and do the checks.
 - Add 'qos_specs' and 'rate_limit' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.
 - Add 'rate_limit', 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.

 a volume create request.

commit_message:
Implement QoS support for volumes

This patch is to implement generic Quality-of-Service(QoS) support for volumes.
The goal is to add an interface so that cloud/Cinder admins can use to set
volume QoS, which can be enforced either in hypervisor or on Cinder back-end
or both. QoS specifications are added as a standalone (only visible to admin)
entity.  So admin can create/update/delete and associate/disassociate QoS
specifications to other entities, in this case volume types.

Note that while it's possible for Cinder to set the granularity of QoS control
to every single volume, this patch puts the control granularity to the level
of volumes of the same type to minimize the impact of other Cinder parts.
In other words, the design is to bond QoS with volume types. So Cinder admin
can associate volume types with QoS specifications, and volumes of same volume
type share the same QoS specifications.

QoS can mean a lot different things that it's unlikely we can come up with a
interpretation that all vendors can agree on.  So the approach this
implementation takes is to make Quality-of-Service specs as free-from, i.e.
expressed as key/value pairs.

Changes:
 - Add a quality_of_service_specs table, using adjacency list relation to store
 a specs entry and its detailed specs in key/values. Note that to be able to
 distinguish where should the QoS specs be consumed, each QoS specs entity
 will have a 'consumer' (i.e. fixed key) with the value of where admin would
 like the QoS policy to be enforced/consumed, currently these three values are
 considered valid: 'front-end' (Nova Compute), 'back-end' (Cinder back-end),
 'both'. The default value for 'consumer' is 'back-end';
 - Add a new API extension 'qos_specs_manage' to allow list/create/update/
 delete/associate/disassociate of QoS specs;
 - Add volume/qos_specs internal API for qos specs manipulation;
 - Add 'qos_specs' info to data structure when
 initialize_connection() is called.
 - Add 'qos_specs' to request_specs and filter properties for
 a volume create request.

 TODO
 - Modify 'type_manage' API extension to be able to accept qos info.
 - Modify volume_types.create() to accept qos info and do the checks.

DocImpact

implement blueprint: pass-ratelimit-info-to-nova

Change-Id: Iabc61b941aaff10395b30e2045e3421369a317e2

commit_message:
Downgrade subunit

Closes-Bug: #1216231

Sync with openstack/requirements.

Since subunit has released its new version 0.0.14, run tox -epy27
will cause 'unpack requires a string argument of length 1' error
and fail to run unittest. And Jenkins cannot work well too.

We should downgrage it to 0.0.13 untill subunit fix this problem.

Change-Id: Iedaf3422a7b50697225cae495c3202a8e4230889

commit_message:
Downgrade subunit

Closes-Bug: #1216231

Sync with openstack/requirements.

Since subunit has released its new version 0.0.14, run tox -epy27
will cause 'unpack requires a string argument of length 1' error
and fail to run unittest. And Jenkins cannot work well too.

We should downgrage it to 0.0.13 untill subunit fix this problem.

Change-Id: I6d71f86427b6a8906c76fd8fc410e62acd355b2a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/74/43574/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Ensure that setup_requires are installed
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-16 12:50:48.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/pbr/commit/3d9cf21802e90a339599c5b268f940b8a6ddd052', 'message': "Ensure that setup_requires are installed

When setup.py uses easy_install to resolve dependencies, it downloads an
egg into the local dir. Additionally, when python is invoked via
sys.executable and not via a #! line, it prepends '' to sys.path. This
means that when pbr shells out to pip to install install_requirements,
it will consider any locally downloaded eggs to be installed, and so
will erroneously not install them.

To avoid this, make the pip invocation slightly more complex, and strip
'' out of sys.path in the invocation. This should mean that eggs in the
local dir will always be ignored for the purposes of resolving
dependencies, which is the correct behavior.

commit_message:
Ensure that setup_requires are installed

When setup.py uses easy_install to resolve dependencies, it downloads an
egg into the local dir. Additionally, when python is invoked via
sys.executable and not via a #! line, it prepends '' to sys.path. This
means that when pbr shells out to pip to install install_requirements,
it will consider any locally downloaded eggs to be installed, and so
will erroneously not install them.

To avoid this, make the pip invocation slightly more complex, and strip
'' out of sys.path in the invocation. This should mean that eggs in the
local dir will always be ignored for the purposes of resolving
dependencies, which is the correct behavior.

Change-Id: Ic5254396b71b9d3f3f71236d65024125817ddd08
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/pbr refs/changes/38/42338/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: sys.executable, '-c', 'import sys; import pip.__init__;' ' sys.path=[x for x in sys.path if x != ""]; pip.__init__.main()', 'install', root_cmd,

subject: Stop installing PyPI things via apt
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-02 22:01:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/devstack/commit/2aaea261766ceea6ade1da4d96ab840d26f10e0f', 'message': "Stop installing PyPI things via apt

It may, and in fact, it is, completely baffling to behold, but it turns
out that the interaction between distro installed and pip installed
libraries is not a good one. In fact, it's a completely and total
disaster which shows clearly the work of a bunch of provicial-minded
people who don't know how to cooperate or admit that someone else might
have a different opinion.

Nonetheless, thus is the world in which we actually exist, theory of how
things should be notwithstanding. We were requested by the distros to
stop managing our own apt repos, so we install our depends via pip now.
Additionally, we now actually even GATE on the pip requirements list.
That means that the requirements list that indicates packages from PyPI
is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

Thus - installing those packages also via apt is a not only a waste of
time, it's dangerous because of the undefined interactions between
distro and pip.

Change-Id: I18e480a3312078bde26fc590d4d793e0795e7078

libraries is not a good one. In fact, it's a completely and total
disaster which shows clearly the work of a bunch of provicial-minded
people who don't know how to cooperate or admit that someone else might
have a different opinion.

Nonetheless, thus is the world in which we actually exist, theory of how
things should be notwithstanding. We were requested by the distros to
stop managing our own apt repos, so we install our depends via pip now.
Additionally, we now actually even GATE on the pip requirements list.
That means that the requirements list that indicates packages from PyPI
is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

Thus - installing those packages also via apt is a not only a waste of
time, it's dangerous because of the undefined interactions between
distro and pip.

Change-Id: I18e480a3312078bde26fc590d4d793e0795e7078

commit_message:
Stop installing PyPI things via apt

It may, and in fact, it is, completely baffling to behold, but it turns
out that the interaction between distro installed and pip installed
libraries is not a good one. In fact, it's a completely and total
disaster which shows clearly the work of a bunch of provicial-minded
people who don't know how to cooperate or admit that someone else might
have a different opinion.

Nonetheless, thus is the world in which we actually exist, theory of how
things should be notwithstanding. We were requested by the distros to
stop managing our own apt repos, so we install our depends via pip now.
Additionally, we now actually even GATE on the pip requirements list.
That means that the requirements list that indicates packages from PyPI
is the absolute and total list of requirements in the form that we can
manage.

Thus - installing those packages also via apt is a not only a waste of
time, it's dangerous because of the undefined interactions between
distro and pip.

Also, we an properly install the dev libs we need here, so that other
dev and test works right.

Closes-Bug: 1203723
Change-Id: I18e480a3312078bde26fc590d4d793e0795e7078

Handle the credentials as object

This refactorization makes simpler future credentials
 related changes.

- per process credential management

commit_message:
Remove ch_dochistory, use section_dochistory instead

Like in all other guides, let's place the history in the preface
and use section_dochistory instead of ch_dochistory.

Also, the config guide had a chapter called overview. Mark it as
preface like in all other guides.

Change-Id: I4de28356456286c7f3d7a340cf27f233d52cdfec

commit_message:
Replace using tests.utils part2

It is the second step to replace using tests.utils with
stack.common.test.
In this patch second part of tests is changed for using
openstack.common.test and added needed fixtures in test classes.

Change-Id: I81e3ff41827f7153b650255e219ce25cb282507b

commit_message:
Catch the correct exception

ConfigParser.parse throws cfg.ParseError not the one in iniparser.
(note that cfg.py#L1231 has a reference to filename which is not
present in the initparser.ParseError)

Change-Id: I742ac254dbfb35d5a69b82b54a262d0341637f3d

commit_message:
Fix for consumer update for SQL backend

I noticed this while testing keystoneclient, the update for
consumer wasn't working because a new session was being
generated from _get_consumer.

fixes bug: #1215483

Change-Id: I0b6c96d403081368d3c227075333f7433ba35ee1
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/keystone refs/changes/84/43184/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: old_con_ref = session.query(Consumer).get(consumer_id) if old_con_ref is None: raise exception.NotFound(_('Consumer not found')) old_consumer_dict = old_con_ref.to_dict() new_con_ref = Consumer.from_dict(old_consumer_dict) for attr in Consumer.attributes: if (attr == 'description'): setattr(old_con_ref, attr, getattr(new_con_ref, attr)) old_con_ref.extra = new_con_ref.extra return core.filter_consumer(old_con_ref.to_dict())
deleted_lines: consumer_ref = self._get_consumer(consumer_id) old_consumer_dict = consumer_ref.to_dict() new_consumer = Consumer.from_dict(old_consumer_dict) for attr in Consumer.attributes: if (attr != 'id' or attr != 'secret'): setattr(consumer_ref, attr, getattr(new_consumer, attr)) consumer_ref.extra = new_consumer.extra return core.filter_consumer(consumer_ref.to_dict())

commit_message:
Fix Fibre Channel attach for single WWN

The code allowed for only a string of the WWN or a list of them.
Unfortunately unicode is also returned, for which the attach fails.
This patch allows for unicode as well.

Change-Id: I1d81abc3f8569ce8b3fb25c0e9c8aefd10e9aae8
Fixes: bug 1214413

commit_message:
Move flake8 option from run_tests.sh to tox.ini

flake8 will read the section [flake8] of tox.ini to guide the behavior.
In run_tests.sh, there is no need to add flake8 option in run_flake8()
function.

Bug #1214175

Change-Id: If3b84a0a3eecc1a9800fed6be9b24e648c161280

commit_message:
Enforce flavor access during instance boot

The code in the servers API did not pass the context when retrieving
flavor details.  That means it would use an admin context instead,
bypassing all flavor access control checks.

This patch includes the fix, and the corresponding unit test for the v2
API.

Closes-bug: #1212179

(cherry picked from commit 4054cc4a22a1fea997dec76afb5646fd6c6ea6b9)

Conflicts:
	nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/servers.py
	nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/test_servers.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/test_servers.py

Change-Id: I681ae9965e19767df22fa74c3315e4e03a459d3b

commit_message:
Sync py3kcompat from oslo

Python3 reorganized the standard library and moved several
functions to different modules and combined modules. Six
provides a consistent interface to the module through
six.moves

However urllib/urlparse is not covered by six.moves so
py3kcompat adds python2/python3 compatibility layer for
urllib/urlparse.

Change-Id: If1436d2260f1c8b6df8c514c8730e7bcf0e648b8
Signed-off-by: Chuck Short <chuck.short@canonical.com>

commit_message:
Update from openstack/requirements

Pull in current requirments settings from
openstack/requirements.

This also requires that the test_image_utils test
is updated, it's currently raising and assertRaise
on a generic Exception which is now an H202 violation.

We'll pick one of the valid exceptions that can come
from mkstemp and use it.

Change-Id: I170afd30f2348c8bb82c30b7f624f959da227731

commit_message:
Protected matcher import

In python the names starts with '_'should not be used from another
package/distribution without a good reason.

The matchers are reachable from a not protected namespace.

Change-Id: I8892599edcbe7c4dd1cebea2c99e81a3221f8ef5

commit_message:
Use the same root test class.

Instead of being strongly tied to unittest2 make
it easier for taskflow to switch to another root
class by abstracting out the unittest2 usage.

This also enables some useful functionality to exist
in that root test class that other tasks can take
advantage of.

Change-Id: I90fb98150476ff56e0455c24d852e52d16eb4890

[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-06-06 00:38:17.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/c995d110ac3f34de4e397904776e2deef98eaf56', 'message': "Set GZIP to -1 for tarball creation in XenServer

Images will default to gzip -6, which is quite CPU intensive. -1 is
much faster, at a slight trade off of size. -1 appears to be 30-50%
faster in real world snapshot speed, with maybe 10-20% lower
compression. As this is an environment setting, I can't see it breaking
anything across varying deployments. This should be a configurable
option in the future, but I feel for now it's a good interim improvement
to the imaging process.

commit_message:
nova.conf configurable gzip compression level

Currently only used by XenAPI.

Sets GZIP environment variable before spawning tar -cz to force the
compression level. Defaults to none, which means the GZIP environment
variable is not set and the default (usually -6) is used.

Implements: blueprint image-compression-mode

Change-Id: I02e136b7215a4f2cefc259f40bde9c1b205737ed
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/98/31898/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: os.putenv("GZIP", "-1") os.unsetenv("GZIP")

Add tasks data model

Partially implement bp async-glance-workers

commit_message:
Fix signature of _create_volume() in ThinLVMVolumeDriver

create_volume_from_snapshot will call _create_volume() with the
wrong parameters when using ThinLVMVolumeDriver.  It should be
compatible with LVMVolumeDriver's _create_volume() method.

Fixes bug: 1210853

Conflicts:
	cinder/volume/drivers/lvm.py

(cherry picked from commit 7323d8751538e06bb2dba106ba394bc6e29b8b84)
Change-Id: I18f7baf60601b3bcf01425b505a0579a826f072e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/74/41274/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Run models unittest after database migrations.

Changeset I3939e474aa6e8e5549b1d89725e988dd056400d9 introduced testing
of the expected schemas, this change also applies these tests to a
migrated database.

Change-Id: I5ff8c223e270f951c3f205f465ca828f334f21a7

commit_message:
boot an instance will fail if use "--hint group=XXXXX"

When use command "nova boot --image <image name> --flavor <flavor id>
--hint group=<group uuid> vm1", booting will fail.

To fix this issue, should use utils.metadata_to_dict to translate
metadata to dict and then update dict.

Change-Id: I850fef968115cd120a2a760f1207a01c683ef558
Fixes: bug #1213149

commit_message:
Cleanup: Add common "ssh-login server" method

There are some "ssh-login server" methods in scenario tests, and
they will increase in the future by increasing scenario tests.
This patch adds common "ssh-login server" method to parent class
and uses it instead of each implementation.

Change-Id: Iefee90b7a79b85b67694bc32382b4c4d776bc5b2

commit_message:
Pin python-subunit to 0.0.13

0.0.14 is broken due to:

  https://bugs.launchpad.net/subunit/+bug/1216163

described in that bug.

commit_message:
Fix the Domain Context for Users panel

Add display of Domain ID and Domain Name in the Create and Update
Users page to give user a hint where the User will be created.
For Keystone V2, the two fields will be hidden.

When the Domain Context is set, the User will be created in that
Domain Context. Otherwise, the User will be created in the Domain
of the logon user.

On users creation, the listing of available projects will be based
on the Domain where it will be created.

Fixes bug 1215697

Change-Id: I98a2161004054a41e2311ef12aec6335b87aa856

commit_message:
Add a has_interface() method to the resource class

This is to better indentify resource types, given that they
can be mapped in the environment.

Change-Id: I6dd552c87b80eb34baec306acd663657ee929b30

commit_message:
Remove unused methods from LVM driver

_set_execute() has been unused since b569df9, and _size_str() has
been done since f4a9429. So this patch removes them for clean-up.

Change-Id: If8a2703afb08623b69ec6adc105cf58b0e4a15dc
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/04/43404/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def _set_execute(self, execute): self._execute = execute def _size_str(self, size_in_g): if '.00' in size_in_g: size_in_g = size_in_g.replace('.00', '') if int(size_in_g) == 0: return '100m' return '%sg' % size_in_g

commit_message:
3PAR driver clone volume doc updates

Adding the -online option to the operation that is called on the
3PAR backend changed what extra specs keys are supported for
cloned volumes. This patch adds a note on exactly what is supported
now. The -online option was added to resolve some performance issues

Change-Id: Idada7b2ae12b97953ed36d865f129574bb39be96
Fixes: bug 1211974
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/45/43545/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <note> <para>Volumes that have been cloned will only support extra specs keys cpg, snap_cpg, provisioning and vvs, the others will be ignored. In addition the comments section of the cloned volume in the HP 3PAR StoreServ storage array will not be populated. </para> </note>

commit_message:
Install MySQL-python<1.2.4 for virtualenv

The latest version(1.2.4) of MySQL-python can not be install
properly, then the virtualenv is cleanup.

Designate MySQL-python<1.2.4 in test-requirements.txt.

Bug #1213014

Change-Id:Ie9cc538bba2874bc626934e326831a70da632178

commit_message:
Fixes sync issue for user level resources

fixed/floating ips and networks can't be synced properly because they're
tracked per user in the quota table but they're not tied to a user so
it's not feasible to grab a count of how many are being used by any
particular user. So the quota_usages table can get into a bad state if
it sync with user level.
Sync these resources with project level, and set quota with project
level to solve the problem.

Fixes bug 1214523

Change-Id: Icd94e95fb706ee90e0737e85cfa50f05ff3c0ff8

commit_message:
Fix migration downgrade 146 with mysql

Add availability zones back in individually to work with MySQL downgrades
on migration 146.

Fixes bug 1207956

Change-Id: I48b3ce27b92f231e280ee5af7a3e1b8ce6c4b018
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/36/40136/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Migrate data back # NOTE(jhesketh): This needs to be done with individual inserts as multiple # results in an update sub-query do not work with MySQL. See bug/1207956. record_list = list(aggregates.select().execute()) for rec in record_list: result = aggregate_metadata.select().where( aggregate_metadata.c.key == 'availability_zone' ).where( aggregate_metadata.c.aggregate_id == rec['id'] ) aggregates.update().values( availability_zone=list(result.execute())[0]['value'] ).where( aggregates.c.id == rec['id'] ).execute()

commit_message:
Remove the indexes on downgrade to work with MySQL

Fixes MySQL downgrade on migration 203.
Add tests to check the indexes.

Fixes bug 1207174

Change-Id: If50fb49e1c76c2a7512141dae5f1a5818dc1b699

commit_message:
Downgrade MySQL to the same state it used to be

virtual_interfaces_instance_uuid_fkey exists as a KEY, not a UNIQUE KEY in
MySQL which causes trouble when downgrading.

Don't re-create the virtual_interfaces_instance_uuid_fkey on downgrade as it
wasn't upgraded properly and therefore still exists. This forces the downgrade
to look exactly like it was before the upgrade.

Fixes bug 1207344

Change-Id: Id1700e1cbba669df2dd8e5c5a842b859577aa32c

commit_message:
Add more tests for Swift Account Quota

2 new tests are added:

+ test that the admin is able to modify/remove a quota
  on a user's account

+ test that a user is not able to modify/remove a quota
  on its own account

Change-Id: I54cad8b244a26be8445fa4fe9ea63785aef4472a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/99/41099/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @testtools.skipIf(not accounts_quotas_available, "Account Quotas middleware not available") @attr(type=["smoke"]) def test_admin_modify_quota(self): """Test that the ResellerAdmin is able to modify and remove the quota on a user's account. Using the custom_account client, the test modifies the quota successively to: * "25": a random value different from the initial quota value. * "" : an empty value, equivalent to the removal of the quota. * "20": set the quota to its initial value. """ for quota in ("25", "", "20"): headers = {"X-Auth-Token": self.reselleradmin_token, "X-Account-Meta-Quota-Bytes": "25"} resp, _ = self.os.custom_account_client.request("POST", "", headers, "") self.assertEqual(resp["status"], "204") @testtools.skipIf(not accounts_quotas_available, "Account Quotas middleware not available") @attr(type=["negative", "smoke"]) def test_user_modify_quota(self): """Test that a user is not able to modify or remove a quota on its account. """ # Note: # # If I try to use the "delete_account_metadata" method, I get # a weird error. # # self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, # self.account_client.delete_account_metadata, # ["Quota-Bytes"]) # Not able to remove quota self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.account_client.create_account_metadata, {"Quota-Bytes": ""}) # Not able to modify quota self.assertRaises(exceptions.Unauthorized, self.account_client.create_account_metadata, {"Quota-Bytes": "100"})

commit_message:
Fix skip tracker regex for multi-line skips

This commit changes the regex used for detecting a skip line by
removing the requirement on an '(' immediately following 'skip'.
This changes the skip tracker to match multiline skips (assuming
'skip' is on the same line as the bug number. It also enables
conditional skips that have a bug number from being picked up.

Change-Id: I95a0521661084034f7625c3c517ae9210120de4c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/24/42424/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BUG_RE = re.compile(r'.*skip.*bug:*\s*\#*(\d+)', re.IGNORECASE)

commit_message:
Remove invalid block_device_mapping volume_size of ''

Parsing block_device_mapping from strings sometimes results in
volume_size being set to '' or u''.  This causes a problem when
inserting into PostgreSQL, which insists that integer columns
actually contain integers.  Remove invalid device_size before
inserting or updating block_device_mapping database records.

(cherry picked from commit 188a94c898bcf07f9fe42ef2f3b5ee4aa8859b49)

Fixes: Bug #1171190
Change-Id: If9132a96604b5b0e3a6df96624e565e016d5c9a3

commit_message:
XenAPI: Return platform_version if no product_version

Nova now requires a version to be set.  In the case of xapi-XCP/xenserver-core
no product_version exists, so use the platform_version instead.

Fixes bug 1206948

Change-Id: I4d6008216075716c8b969493b7a2ccb7713f755d

subject: XenAPI: Support local connections
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-15 13:27:44.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/1266c954e5943be99973be9867afeb014fff38f5', 'message': 'XenAPI: Support local connections

Currently there is no way to connect to XAPI through the unix socket,
requiring a URL and credentials.

This change allows you to run in dom0 (particularly in xenserver-core

commit_message:
XenAPI: Support local connections

Currently there is no way to connect to XAPI through the unix socket,
requiring a URL and credentials.

This change allows you to run in dom0 (particularly in xenserver-core
environments) and connect to XAPI using the unix domain socket by
specifying "unix://local"
DocImpact

Change-Id: I3d5ace31c9c0411fa711cfdf87383d36f61bfa4a

commit_message:
Stub out entry points in LookupTorrentURLTestCase

Torrent URL lookup functions are registered via entry-points.

If the tests run in an environment where the production lookup function is
present, it will use that; not what we want for tests.

Instead, we should stubout entry-points so we have a mock URL lookup function.

Fixes bug 1211396

Change-Id: Ibc2b34bfdcecaad4c53fb00e925a8b21965d8577

commit_message:
Revert "Make compute_capabilities_filter use ..."

This reverts commit a4ad62ac9fdacecfbc5229e688a7d937d177889b.

Nova baremetal architecture scheduling was broken by it. While
workarounds exist it is backwards incompatible, and baremetal is
supported since Grizzly.

Fix bug: 1213967

Change-Id: I319b8a17f3ae7a3b527d388c6ff2954c0bcc0108

commit_message:
Remove "N309 Python 3.x incompatible construct"

This check was implemented as H231 in Hacking 0.6 or newer
(I0bd89fa05d88de34ca62ce59f427468ede226126),
so the duplicate implementation can be removed.

Change-Id: I003d8611621adc53f1afcfd77691f345397670b0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/08/40108/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: def except_python3x_compatible(logical_line, filename): """Check for except statements to be Python 3.x compatible As of Python 3.x, the construct "except x,y:" has been removed. N308 """ def is_old_style_except(logical_line): # Should match: # except ProcessExecutionError, exn: # Should not match: # except UncodeError: # except (x,y): return (',' in logical_line and ')' not in logical_line.rpartition(',')[2]) if ("except " in logical_line and logical_line.endswith(':') and is_old_style_except(logical_line)): yield(0, "N308: Python 3.x incompatible 'except x,y:' construct") register(except_python3x_compatible)

commit_message:
Fix exception handling in V3 API coverage extension

Commit 616098dcd36b20e01d38898b8942003df664e6ac fixed the exception
handling in the V2 version of the coverage extension so backtrace
information is not lost when an exception is reraised. This applies
the same fix to the V3 version

Change-Id: I29ec1492c2def9c60c8ff471683914ae2943966e

commit_message:
Allow swap_volume to be called by Cinder

This allows Cinder to call swap_volume as part of a volume migration.
Cinder creates the new volume and calls Nova to perform the swap. When
Nova finishes, it calls Cinder to complete the migration, where it
updates the volume metadata so that the volume ID remains unchanged.
Thus, if Cinder detects that the migration was initiated by Cinder, it
will return the original volume ID to keep using. Otherwise, it will
return the new volume's ID for Nova to use, which is what it had done
before.

Change-Id: If352f2e11701148a5aeccaf7fd6379528fa8be31
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/98/41298/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Refactor plugin API methods

* Supported method now must respond to an enumeration
* Modified encrypt/generate_data_encryption_key to use supports
* Refactor a bunch of confusing kek_meta_tenant, kek_metadata,
* kek_meta_dto things
* Modify plugins to support new method signatures in abstract base class
* Unit tests for more error conditions
* Hacking fixes (but many more needed...)

Change-Id: I33c20959f145f1c8f22725f62fb410033080b64f
Implements: blueprint crypto-refine-is-supported
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/barbican refs/changes/33/43333/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from barbican.crypto.plugin import PluginSupportTypes def test_supports_encrypt_decrypt(self): self.assertTrue( self.plugin.supports(PluginSupportTypes.ENCRYPT_DECRYPT) ) def test_supports_symmetric_key_generation(self): self.assertTrue( self.plugin.supports(PluginSupportTypes.SYMMETRIC_KEY_GENERATION) ) def test_does_not_support_unknown_type(self): self.assertFalse( self.plugin.supports("SOMETHING_RANDOM") )

subject: 3PAR driver clone volume doc updates
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2013-08-22 19:09:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/e3e2c1fa60a6b3edca037153014acf8fb8dd0d11', 'message': '3PAR driver clone volume doc updates

Adding the -online option to the operation that is called on the
3PAR backend changed what extra specs keys are supported for
cloned volumes. This patch adds a note on exactly what is supported
now. The -online option was added to resolve some performance issues.

commit_message:
3PAR driver clone volume doc updates

Adding the -online option to the operation that is called on the
3PAR backend changed what extra specs keys are supported for
cloned volumes. This patch adds a note on exactly what is supported
now. The -online option was added to resolve some performance issues.

Change-Id: I67dd41055d226f8d0c8f8800e6fd9be94c8768e0
Fixes: bug 1211974
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals refs/changes/30/43330/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: <note> <para>Volumes that have been cloned will only support values extra specs keys cpg, snap_cpg, provisioning and vvs, the others will be ignored. In addition the comments section of the cloned volume in the HP 3PAR StoreServ storage array will not be popluated. </para> </note>

commit_message:
image-delete fires multiple queries to delete its child entries

1. Changed individual query calls for soft-deleting the image's
   child entries to one db query call for all child entries of a
   given type.
2. Added a fix to simple db's 'image_destroy' api to clear
   the location entries.

Fixes bug 1201758

Change-Id: Ib673de5460d59ea3af74553048ffcf74dccbdc36
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/glance refs/changes/14/37214/8 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: _image_locations_delete_all(context, image_ref.id, session) _image_property_delete_all(context, image_id, session=session) _image_member_delete_all(context, image_id, session=session) _image_tag_delete_all(context, image_id, session=session)def _image_locations_delete_all(context, image_id, session=None): """Delete all image locations for given image""" locs_updated_count = _image_delete_all(models.ImageLocation, image_id, session) return locs_updated_count def _image_delete_all(child_model_cls, image_id, session=None): """Deletes all the child entries for the given image id. Deletes all the child entries of the given child entry ORM model class using the parent image's id. The child entry ORM model class can be one of the following: model.ImageLocation, model.ImageProperty, model.ImageMember and model.ImageTag. :param child_model_cls: the ORM model class. :param image_id: id of the image whose child entries are to be deleted. :param session: A SQLAlchemy session to use (if present) :rtype: int :return: The number of child entries got soft-deleted. """ session = session or _get_session() query = session.query(child_model_cls) \ .filter_by(image_id=image_id) \ .filter_by(deleted=False) count = query.update({"deleted": True, "deleted_at": timeutils.utcnow()}) return count def _image_property_delete_all(context, image_id, session=None): """Delete all image properties for given image""" props_updated_count = _image_delete_all(models.ImageProperty, image_id, session) return props_updated_count def _image_member_delete_all(context, image_id, session=None): """Delete all image members for given image""" members_updated_count = _image_delete_all(models.ImageMember, image_id, session) return members_updated_count def _image_tag_delete_all(context, image_id, session=None): """Delete all image tags for given image""" tags_updated_count = _image_delete_all(models.ImageTag, image_id, session) return tags_updated_count
deleted_lines: _image_locations_set(image_ref.id, [], session) for prop_ref in image_ref.properties: image_property_delete(context, prop_ref.name, image_id, session=session) members = _image_member_find(context, session, image_id=image_id) for memb_ref in members: _image_member_delete(context, memb_ref, session) tag_values = image_tag_get_all(context, image_id, session=session) for tag_value in tag_values: image_tag_delete(context, image_id, tag_value, session=session)

commit_message:
Enforce flavor access during instance boot

The code in the servers API did not pass the context when retrieving
flavor details.  That means it would use an admin context instead,
bypassing all flavor access control checks.

This patch includes the fix, and the corresponding unit test for the v2
API.

Closes-bug: #1212179

(cherry picked from commit 4054cc4a22a1fea997dec76afb5646fd6c6ea6b9)

Conflicts:
	nova/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/servers.py
	nova/api/openstack/compute/servers.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/plugins/v3/test_servers.py
	nova/tests/api/openstack/compute/test_servers.py

Change-Id: I681ae9965e19767df22fa74c3315e4e03a459d3b

commit_message:
Added parted to the list of packages to install on debian family

Parted is not installed by default on Debian system, and provides the command
partprobe needed in disk-image-create.

Change-Id: Ie03173398e425d65a908f25a880538a4912494b2
